reasonsForBeingOther.label: No proofs
reasonsForBeingOther.shortDescription: The proof system isn't fully functional
reasonsForBeingOther.description: Projects without a proper proof system fully rely on single entities to safely update the state. A malicious proposer can finalize an invalid state, which can cause loss of funds.

display.name: Jovay
display.description: Jovay, by Ant Digital Technologies, is an Ethereum Layer 2 blockchain built for real-world assets and users.

layer.description: The data is posted to Ethereum as calldata or blobs.

bridge.description: The validating bridge has access to all the data, as it is posted onchain.

query.functionSignature: function verifyBatch(uint8 _prove_type, bytes _batchHeader, bytes32 _postStateRoot, bytes32 _l2MsgRoot, bytes _proof)

stateValidation.description: State roots are accepted when attested by a permissioned TEE through the TEEVerifierProxy. There is no challenge mechanism and no validity proofs can be submitted.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: Users can submit transactions to an L1 queue, but can't force them. The sequencers cannot selectively skip transactions but can stop processing the queue entirely. In other words, if the sequencers censor or are down, they are so for everyone.

proposerFailure.description: Only the whitelisted proposers can publish state roots on L1, so in the event of failure the withdrawals are frozen.

dataAvailability.name: All data required for proofs is published on chain
dataAvailability.description: All the data that is used to construct the system state is published on chain in the form of cheap blobs or calldata. This ensures that it will be available for enough time.

references.title: Rollup.sol - commitBatch stores calldata hashes for each batch
L1Mailbox.sol - sendMsg enqueues transactions on Ethereum

operator.name: The system has a centralized operator
operator.description: The operator is the only entity that can propose blocks. A live and trustworthy operator is vital to the health of the system.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

references.title: Rollup.sol - addRelayer is restricted to the owner

forceTransactions.name: Users can enqueue transactions
forceTransactions.description: Users can submit transactions to an L1 queue, but can't force them. The sequencer cannot selectively skip transactions but can stop processing the queue entirely. In other words, if the sequencer censors or is down, it is so for everyone.

risks.text: the operator is offline or refuses to process the queue.

references.title: Rollup.sol - commitBatch function passes the totalL1MessagePopped as input parameter

exitMechanisms.name: Regular messaging
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates L2->L1 messages by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is settled, the message becomes available for processing on L1.

roles.name: Proposer
roles.description: Allowed to post new state roots of the current layer to the host chain.

roles.name: Sequencer
roles.description: Allowed to commit transactions from the current layer to the host chain.

actors.description:
* Can upgrade **with no delay**
  * L1ETHBridge 
  * L1Mailbox 
  * Rollup

actors.name: EOA 1 and EOA 2
actors.description:
* A Proposer - acting directly
* A Sequencer - acting directly

ethereum.name: L1Mailbox
ethereum.description:
The L1Mailbox contract is used to send messages to the L2.
* Roles:
  * **admin**:

ethereum.name: Rollup
ethereum.description:
The Rollup contract is used to submit and verify L2 batches.
* Roles:
  * **admin**: 
  * **relayer**: EOA 1, EOA 2

ethereum.name: L1ETHBridge
ethereum.description:
The L1ETHBridge contract is used to bridge ETH between the L1 and L2.
* Roles:
  * **admin**:

ethereum.name: DcapAttestationRouter
ethereum.description: The DcapAttestationRouter contract is used for routing and verifying Intel SGX/TDX DCAP attestation proofs. The contract sends each quote to the corresponding verification path (cache verifier vs. Automata DCAP contract, and SGX vs. TDX measurement checks).

ethereum.name: MeasurementDao
ethereum.description: The MeasurementDao contract is an onchain registry that allowlists SGX MR_ENCLAVE<->MR_SIGNER pairs and TDX RTMR3/MRTD values, and verifies DCAP quotes by matching quote fields to the stored measurements.

ethereum.name: TEEVerifierProxy
ethereum.description: The TEEVerifierProxy contract is used to verify L2 batches using TEE attestations. It delegates proof verification to the dcapAttestationRouter contract.

ethereum.name: TEECacheVerifier
ethereum.description: A cache-enabled P-256 ECDSA verifier for Intel SGX/TDX DCAP quotes (v3/v4/v5) that authenticates local attestation data, extracts the 32-byte commitment, and lets the owner/authorized callers initialize, manage, and reuse cached attestation keys to skip repeat verifications.

ethereum.name: AutomataDcapAttestationFee
ethereum.description: Contract used to charge a configurable basis-point fee to verify Intel DCAP quotes. Currently set to 0 basis points.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.
